thread.title: Bethlehem's Austin Fox leads way for Section II state golf qualifiers
thread.title_full: Bethlehem's Austin Fox leads way for Section II state golf qualifiers - Times Union

author: Pete Dougherty
title: Bethlehem's Austin Fox leads way for Section II state golf qualifiers
text:
Image 1 of / 2 Caption
Close
Image 1 of 2 The nine players who made the Section II team for next June's state tournament pose at Orchard Creek (from left): Kyle Adams and Jack O'Hara of CBA, Matt Espey of Hoosic Valley, Noah Bonn of Queensbury, Tommy McPartlon of Shenendehowa, Sean Puleo and John Malicki of Albany Academy, Austin Fox of Bethlehem, and Christian Gramuglia of Burnt Hills. (Pete Dougherty/Times Union) The nine players who made the Section II team for next June's state tournament pose at Orchard Creek (from left): Kyle Adams and Jack O'Hara of CBA, Matt Espey of Hoosic Valley, Noah Bonn of Queensbury, ... more Image 2 of 2 Buy photo Bethlehem's Austin Fox hits a fairway shot during the Section II golf championship at Orchard Creek Golf Course on Tuesday, Oct. 13, 2015, in Guilderland, N.Y. (Lori Van Buren / Times Union) Bethlehem's Austin Fox hits a fairway shot during the Section II golf championship at Orchard Creek Golf Course on Tuesday, Oct. 13, 2015, in Guilderland, N.Y. (Lori Van Buren / Times Union) Buy this photo Photo: Lori Van Buren Bethlehem's Austin Fox leads way for Section II state golf qualifiers 1 / 2 Back to Gallery Altamont
It wasn't enough that Austin Fox was blowing away the field Thursday in the Section II golf state qualifier at Orchard Creek.
Just for show, Fox, a sophomore at Bethlehem, rolled in a 40-foot birdie putt at No. 16. Then, after putting his approach shot on the par-5 18th into a hazard, he took his penalty stroke and chipped in for birdie.
It was a flamboyant finish to a second straight 2-under-par 69 that gave Fox a whopping 12-shot victory and a berth on the nine-player section's state team.
"I don't know how it happened," Fox said of his chip-in that gave him a 36-hole score of 4-under 138. "My short game has been really good this year. It has helped me drop a lot of strokes.
The CBA tandem of Jack O'Hara and Kyle Adams came in second and third with scores of 150 and 151, respectively.
"The kid's incredible," said Adams, a senior who qualified for states for the first time. "The kid just doesn't miss a putt."
O'Hara added, "I like playing with kids that play better and try to copy what they're doing and try to stay with them. It helps me play a lot better. It was great playing with him. He's so good."
The 12-stroke margin is believed to be the largest in the history of the qualifier — not bad for someone who didn't even make the 43-player field for last year's state qualifier opening round.
"My goal was just to get on the state team," Fox said, "but to win this tournament is a bonus."
His older brother Victor, now a junior on the Maryland golf team, won this event twice, but his largest margin was seven.
It was evident early on that no one would challenge the younger Fox, who began the round two shots ahead of Shenendehowa's Tommy McPartlon. Fox birdied the first, and it was game on.
After finishing the front nine at even par to push his lead to five, Fox birdied three of the final five holes while his challengers struggled.
"It's never in the bag until it's over," Fox said. "I played as hard as I can and do the best I can."
The course played much more difficult than for the opening round. Only three players — Christian Gramuglia (Burnt Hills), Sean Puleo ( Albany Academy ) and Noah Bonn (Queensbury) — bettered their Tuesday score, and all made the state team. Puleo and McPartlon are the lone repeaters.
"It was a lot longer, the pins were unreal, it was windy," said O'Hara, who followed his opening 73 with a 77. "It was really hard today."
O'Hara and Adams played in the final group together Thursday as CBA was one of two schools to advance two players. Albany Academy, with Puleo and John Malicki , was the other.
"I choked last year, so I was a little nervous on the first tee this morning," Adams said. "I shot 79 last year then shot 84. I got to 16 last year and I shanked my iron. I said don't do that again. I hit it on the green — and three-putted that hole."
By that point, Adams had plenty of cushion to make the state team. He just wasn't going to catch Fox. No one was.
a — won playoff for first alternate spot
b — won playoff for second alternate spot
